awd_abstract_narration:
Particle physics considers a vast range of scientific questions, from subatomic to cosmic scales. The University of Chicago Group supported through this award investigates such questions through experimentation at the highest available collision energies at the Large Hadron Collider (the LHC) at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland. These studies are relevant to the understanding of the Universe at its most fundamental level in the fleeting fraction of a second just after the Big Bang, and to why we see the Universe as we do now. The Chicago group is making significant technical and analytical contributions to the ATLAS experiment, one of the major detectors at the LHC.  The integration of research, education, outreach and diversity is also an essential aspect of the Chicago group's mission. Activities focus on coherent themes that address several primary audiences: the research community (REU programs and the recent ICHEP2016), neighborhood (Enrico Fermi Summer Interns Program), the general public (film documentaries) and diversity and inclusion (Expanding Your Horizons Program, Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics).   The group's location on Chicago's South Side brings important opportunities for engaging underserved and underrepresented minority communities in science.  

The specific technical contributions being made by the Chicago group include leading the development of the Fast Track Trigger (the FTK) and upgrades of the hadron Calorimetry (the TileCAL), to allow ATLAS to operate effectively at the very high beam collision rates that are necessary to advance the scientific goals of the experiment.  The group's analytical contributions are focused in several important areas, including studies of final states containing top quarks, b quarks and light quarks, which will be greatly facilitated by the FTK, the TileCAL, and jet substructure tools developed by the group.   These will provide access to Higgs physics, with emphasis on Higgs decays to b bar final states and searches for exotic physics processes such as dark matter and new states of matter in high mass di-jet final states.

por.por_cntn:
The four University of Chicago experimental particle physics faculty participating in the ATLAS experiment and the LAPPD have made major contributions to advance scientific discoveries and training of the next generation of scientists via a coherent program of instrumentation development, commissioning, and operation of the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider, paired with a compelling program of both novel searches for new physics and key measurements of Standard Model processes.

We have leveraged the unprecedented dataset collected by the ATLAS detector in 2015-2018 (Run 2) to both search for signs of new physics using novel methods and to perform detailed measurements of the Standard Model, specifically of electroweak processes and hadronic final states. We played leadership roles in commissioning and operating the hadronic calorimeter and trigger systems of the ATLAS experiment. We have undertaken three significant upgrades of critical detector instrumentation for the High Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC) such as Main Board electronics for the hadronic calorimeter, the calorimeter Global Event Processor, and the Hardware Track Trigger systems. In addition, our faculty played a significant role in the LAPPD Collaboration for developing large-area photodetectors capable of time resolutions measured in pico-seconds, with accompanying sub-millimeter spatial resolution.

We have carried out this multi-faceted yet coherent collider physics and instrumentation program by leveraging decades of expertise in instrumentation and physics analysis, combined with novel ideas and new institutional endeavors in both machine learning and electronics design. We extended sensitivities to groundbreaking discoveries while also establishing a complete experimental particle physics program that trains undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in a broad range of methods, experimental design, leadership, and communication. The fast-timing technology developed by the LAPPD Collaboration is being considered for neutrinoless double-beta decay and positron-emission tomography programs. Incom is now commercially producing the first generation LAPPD modules under license from the University of Chicago. Moreover, we both leveraged and complemented our research activities by enhancing existing activities and building new efforts that broaden the impacts of this research through workforce development, educational outreach, and promoting science literacy.

Modified by: Young-Kee Kim
